Award.AwardTitle: Modeling Thermal Flows and Cold-air Pools in a Small Basin
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to advance the scientific understanding of (1) thermally driven cross-basin flows and how they are modified by heterogeneous vegetation and snow coverage and by larger-scale flows and of (2) nocturnal inflows and outflows through gaps and saddles in the surrounding topography of basins and how they interact with existing cold-air pools. This work has strong potential to improve air quality forecast and transportation safety. This research project will study selected aspects of thermally driven flows and cold-air pools in the Gruenloch, a small Alpine basin. Numerical model simulations are designed to answer questions that are yet poorly understood. The project will be performed in collaboration with scientists at the University of Vienna, Austria, who have been collecting data in the Gruenloch basin for the past 12 years and who plan another, more extensive field program. The topography of the Gruenloch basin and its surroundings is ideally suited for this study. The Gruenloch is known for the development of strong cold-air pools and extreme minimum temperatures, holding the record for the lowest measured temperature in central Europe. The complex topography of the surrounding Alps, including several saddles in the ridgeline of the Gruenloch, allow the formation of larger-scale daytime and nighttime flows that interact with the basin atmosphere.

Intellectual Merit :
The results from this study will advance the understanding of several aspects of thermally driven flows and cold-air pools, which occur frequently in mountainous terrain. The defined questions about the influence of surface conditions and flows induced by the complex surrounding topography on cross-basin flows and the influence of basin outflows and inflows on cold-air pools are yet poorly understood. Observational data will be used to evaluate and improve high-resolution modeling performance in this highly complex terrain.

Broader Impacts :
The scientific findings from this study will advance knowledge on thermally driven flows and cold-air pools that can contribute to improved forecasting of these phenomena, which strongly affect air pollution transport and dispersion, noise propagation, fire propagation, and fog formation in mountainous terrain. Results will be made public through journal publications, conference and invited seminar presentations, and websites. Findings will be incorporated into classroom lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the Grünloch Modeling Study was to investigate selected aspects of thermally driven flows and cold-air pools in small basins using model simulations based on the example of the Grünloch sinkhole in the Austrian Alps. Thermally driven flows and cold-air pools in mountainous terrain can impact, for example, air pollution transport and dispersion, fog formation, and fire propagation, and have therefore the potential to affect human habitations in mountain valleys and basins. In addition to the importance of forecasting cold-air pools correctly, which follows from their potential impact on human populations, numerical weather models have oftentimes shown problems simulating the depth and strength of cold-air pools correctly.

The Grünloch basin, the study area of this project, has the advantage that very strong temperature inversions are known to form in the small basin, which has a width of about 1 km and a depth of about 150 m. In addition, measurements have been made in the basin for several decades, part of which were available to us for model comparison. The data that we used in this study came from a two-day field course at the University of Vienna in Austria. Because of the relatively large number of instruments and the small size of the Grünloch basin, the basin was densely instrumented, which allowed a detailed model comparison of the spatial variations in the surface wind field.

The ridgeline of the topography surrounding the Grünloch is intersected by three major saddles, similar to many large, inhabited basins, which are not completely enclosed but are typically surrounded by heterogeneous terrain. The study has shown that these gaps in the surrounding terrain can facilitate an exchange of air between the basin and the adjacent atmosphere and that these flows through the gaps can interact with the basin cold-air pool. In our simulations, an extremely unidirectional nocturnal outflow occurred through one of the saddles in the topography surrounding the Grünloch basin, which changed direction to an inflow in the morning, driven by the diurnal temperature variation in the basin. The elevation of the lowest saddle also impacted the vertical extent of the basin-floor inversion, with its strongest part confined below the height of the saddle. The cold pool, in turn, influenced the downslope extent of the katabatic flows coming down the basin sidewall. The negative buoyancy, that is, the temperature difference between the near-surface air over the slopes and the adjacent basin atmosphere, which drives the downslope flows, was insufficient to penetrate the strong cold pool. The flows thus separated from the surface near the top of the cold pool to flow across the basin in an elevated jet.

Additional model simulations were run with different surface layer characteristics that can be related to changes in the vegetation cover, for example, from grassland to forest. The simulations showed that such changes in the vegetation cover can significantly alter nighttime cooling and, subsequently, the depth and strength of the basin cold pool.
